results.title: Good soldier Swejk
results.creator_credit: Jiri Trnka and Czechoslovak State Film
results.brief_description:
Featuring Czech puppet animation, this film consists of three episodes in the life of a Swejk - a solider famous in Czech folklore for his awkward ways and clashes with authority. A satire on militarism, “Good Soldier Swejk” is a sly critique of army life depicted with puppets, which were Czech animator Jiri Trnka’s speciality. Swekj has a talent for unsettling his superiors, showing them up for the inept militarists that they are, whilst remaining blissfully unaware of his misdeeds. Episode one: Swejk is sent to buy a black market bottle of cognac for his superior. When he is caught by another officer he is forced to pretend the cognac is water and drink the whole bottle in one go. Episode 2: Swejk takes a train journey with his superior and earns his wrath for rambling on endlessly with various stories that upset those around him. Swejk is arrested when he decides to pull the emergency brake in order to determine that it works. Episode 3: Having misplaced his regiment, Swejk is arrested on suspicion of being a Russian spy whereupon a top criminologist interrogates him. Several officers guarding him proceed to get drunk and sentimental about the fate of their prisoner before escorting him to the courthouse.

Credits: Director, writer, Jiri Trnka ; photography, E. Franek ; music, Vaclav Trojan; editing, H. Lebduskova ; animation, B. Sramek , B. Pojar, J. Karpas.

results.title: Good mothers
results.creator_credit: Carl Theodor Dreyer, Mogens Skot Hansen and Nordisk Films Kompagni
results.brief_description: Using unconventional directional and editing devices, this production provides an insight into Denmark’s progressive laws and social structures that protect mothers and their children. Shows how married and unmarried mothers in Denmark are provided with assistance through the nation-wide system of ‘Mother’s Aid Institution’. Describes in dramatised form the story of an unmarried mother. Free assistance includes pre-natal attention and classes in the care of children. Following the birth of her child in hospital in Copenhagen the mother spends some time at a Mother’s Aid home, where she receives instruction in homecrafts and is trained to earn a living. Also reveals that since 1888, fathers have been required by Danish law to financially support their children until the age of 18. Commentary by Dinah Miller.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Touchstone Pictures, Silver Screen Partners III, Roy Walker, Barry Levinson, Mark Johnson, Keith Denny, Mitch Markowitz and Larry Brezner
results.description: Radio funny man Adrian Cronauer is sent to Vietnam to bring a little comedy back into the lives of the soldiers. After setting up shop, Cronauer delights the G.I.s but shocks his superior officer, Sergeant Major Dickerson, with his irreverent take on the war. While Dickerson attempts to censor Cronauer’s broadcasts, Cronauer pursues a relationship with a Vietnamese girl named Trinh, who shows him the horrors of war first-hand.

results.title: Good morning, Beijing = Beijing ni zao [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Zhang Nuanxin, Beijing Film Academy and Youth Film Studio
results.brief_description: Directed by one of the few women to have become prominent in China’s film industry, this film depicts the head-on collision between socialist and market ethics in 1980s Beijing through the work and romantic lives of a group of young adults. The equilibrium between three friends who work as bus conductors is disturbed as they seize upon new challenges and opportunities that open up to them as a result of economic reforms. Cast includes Ma Xiaoqing and Wang Quan’an. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Good morning Babylon
results.creator_credit: Vittorio Taviani, Paolo Taviani, Giuliani De Negri, Films A2, RA11, Pressman Film Corporation, MK2 Productions and Filmtre
results.brief_description: The Taviani Brothers’ first English language film is a bitter-sweet and joyous celebration of the early days of Hollywood movie making. Based on a true story, the film is a piece of pure and thrilling cinema and features an acclaimed performance by Charles Dance as the legendary director D.W. Griffith. Two Tuscan stonemason brothers decide to leave Italy for the New World when their father’s firm becomes bankrupt. They travel to Hollywood and wangle their way onto the film set of Griffith. They fall in love and celebrate a double wedding, however war soon intervenes to threaten their happiness.
